17.67.text:
Thank you very much
for having me here.

21.07.text: I hope you're having a good time.

24.20.text: I'm here to talk about art and war.

29.01.text:
Before I begin my talk
I would like to have your opinion.

33.85.text: I will show you a few pictures.

36.98.text: I want you to raise your hand

38.77.text:
if you think that these pictures
show a basic human need.

45.29.text:
This is humanitarian aid
in the form of food.

50.70.text:
How many people think
that food is a basic need for humanity?

57.84.text:
One person doesn't think so.
I don't know how they are still alive.

66.37.text:
How many people think
that shelter is a basic human need?

72.57.text:
Again the same person
not raising their hand.

81.39.text:
How many people think
that water is a basic need?

87.11.text:
I'd like you to tell me
if it is a basic need.

90.27.text:
This is a picture
of young children dancing.

100.92.text:
How many people think
this is a basic need?

109.02.text:
I didn't expect quite as many people
to raise their hands.

112.49.text:
To me art and creativity
is absolutely a basic need.

117.38.text:
It creates a lot of challenges
in my work.

122.16.text: I get asked a lot, why art?

128.31.text:
It is usually followed by:
"Without aid, people will die".

132.50.text: Then I say: "Why do I have to choose?"

135.87.text: We don't choose between food and water,

138.91.text:
why do we have to choose
between art and the other things?

143.27.text:
I was speaking to a charity in the UK,
it was shipping aid out to war zones.

150.67.text: I asked if they can take music equipment.

158.51.text:
They said:
“People will die if we don’t take aid.”

162.91.text:
Then I thought maybe I'm naive
and music doesn't have a power.

171.48.text:
I worked in the field of conflict
across the world.

175.21.text:
I saw that theatre, music and culture
is essential to life.

182.72.text: I would like to show it to you today.

188.25.text: I want to start with this quote, it says:

191.21.text:
“If culture is a luxury,
then why suffer for it?

194.79.text: If it was trivial, then why prosecute it?

197.42.text: If it was harmless, then why die for it?”

200.02.text:
This is a quote
connected to the Prince Klaus Foundation.

207.71.text:
For me, it provides a good context
for the talk today.

211.46.text:
First of all, if culture and creativity
wasn't powerful,

216.09.text:
why would artists be the first to be
taken and tortured in a dictatorship?

222.95.text: This is a photograph of a friend of mine

226.01.text:
who was a singer
in the Egyptian revolution.

230.66.text:
Shortly after the revolution
he was taken and tortured

234.51.text: in the Egyptian Museum by the military.

237.92.text: This is one man and a guitar.

240.18.text:
Why is his music so powerful
that it warrants military to torture him?

247.43.text:
To give you context about me,
I'm not from a war zone.

254.81.text:
This is a place called Burnly.
It is next to Manchester in the UK.

259.50.text:
It is a very small town
where people don't generally leave.

264.14.text:
People don't look outwards to the world
for inspiration.

267.33.text:
I never really thought
that I would have a chance to leave.

271.55.text: Then music came into my life.

273.88.text:
Music has been very important to me
and I wouldn't have left without it.

281.78.text:
When I was 10,
my parents bought me a guitar.

285.12.text:
I learned to play it and that
took my life in a different direction.

291.24.text:
I was in a band, started a record label
and made music events around the world.

299.77.text:
how important music can be
in transforming people's lives.

304.58.text:
If nothing else,
creativity can take people on a journey.

309.58.text:
I don't know what that journey is
or where it ends,

311.89.text: but it will definitely do that.

317.47.text:
because it can be made anywhere
and by anybody.

321.11.text: The great thing about art is

323.24.text:
that you don't need a lot of resource
to make it happen.

326.06.text:
This is a photograph
of theatre in the Congo.

329.44.text:
You just need your body,
your voice, it can be made anywhere.

335.98.text:
The most important arts,
the ones I enjoy the most

340.05.text:
are the ones made by people
who need to make it.

345.61.text:
I'm the co-director of an organization
called “In Place Of War”.

349.13.text:
We've been working in conflict zones
for the last 12 years.

357.48.text:
We work with education and
with mobility of artists in war zones.

364.67.text:
We’ve been doing it
in about 40 countries across the world.

368.89.text:
Our work started with one question
and that was:

372.84.text:
Do people make art
when bombs are dropping on their heads?

377.39.text:
We started exploring theatre
in places of conflict.

381.39.text: We were asking: Does theatre happen?

384.25.text:
If it does,
how and why are people doing theatre?

389.33.text: To cut a long story short,

392.61.text:
in every place of conflict
people are making theatre.

399.71.text:
That theatre might change
but it is always being produced.

405.56.text: This threw a question at me which was:

410.97.text:
that they are still doing it
at the most challenging times?

418.06.text:
So I want to show you a few examples
of different artistic practice

424.82.text:
That manages to do something
which wouldn't exist without art.

437.16.text:
This is a satirical news program,
called the “ZambeziNews”.

442.58.text:
They are now in Berlin
and performing on Wednesday.

448.70.text:
What they do with satire
is quite incredible.

454.68.text:
When I went to Zimbabwe
for the first time,

456.80.text:
I tried to have a conversation
in a local bar about politics.

461.96.text:
This was a no-go.
It was not talked about.

465.82.text: People were scared of being tortured.

469.61.text:
All these things
are a reality in Zimbabwe.

473.19.text:
So this program satirizes
the government in a news program.

481.69.text:
They produce it on DVD
and distribute it and streamed it online.

487.77.text:
They reach 9 million people
in Zimbabwe with the program.

493.79.text:
it might seem normal
to produce this kind of program.

503.34.text:
where people can question the government,
they can provocate and satirize.

509.67.text: For me this is really powerful.

513.82.text: These guys also create a festival.

518.01.text:
Again, they have a festival here
of hip-hop and spoken word.

522.17.text:
You cannot talk about politics in a bar
but you can go onstage and talk about it.

530.20.text:
Last year I went to a festival
where “ZambeziNews” performed.

534.24.text:
It was in front of the building
of Mugabe's party.

541.92.text:
This was one of the most political acts
I have ever seen.

546.82.text:
Thousands of people were looking
how Robert Mugabe was being satirized.

553.11.text:
This shows
the power of satire in this space.

559.48.text:
Talking about space,
it is very important

563.54.text:
in terms of making transformation
within communities.

569.45.text: It is in Rio de Janeiro in Brazil.

572.93.text:
It started out as a community newspaper
in a place which is very challenging

583.40.text:
This community newspaper
evolved in a multifaceted creative space

588.79.text:
where young people
can learn drama and dance.

593.58.text:
This space engages people
in positive activity

596.87.text:
that they otherwise
wouldn't be able to involve in.

601.02.text: This is another space I really like,

603.31.text:
it is based in Caracas in Venezuela
in a dangerous ghetto.

609.50.text:
It is a creative space
made out of shipping containers.

614.76.text:
Every week, 500 young people
come out of the violence surrounding them

624.93.text:
there won't be any other option
for people in this neighborhood.

631.53.text:
this is a photograph
of an orchestra called “El Sistema”.

635.46.text:
It is an orchestra where young people
can learn classical instruments.

643.27.text:
When I visited Venezuela,
one of the most surprising things

648.70.text: was when I was talking to a boy.

651.34.text: He was a percussionist in this orchestra.

653.72.text:
I went to his house and we was
playing his percussion, he was amazing.

658.60.text:
“Every day I have to travel
from school to the orchestral rehearsal.

666.64.text:
It is very dangerous.
Every day I risk my life to play.

670.74.text: But as soon as I sit down,

673.97.text:
it takes me out of the reality
of my everyday life.”

678.40.text: His percussion was everything to him.

681.14.text:
It gave him the alternative
to the dangerous reality he lives in.

688.45.text: This is another space in Sri Lanka.

693.11.text:
This is called
“The Butterfly Peace Garden”.

695.60.text:
It was set up during a time
of civil unrest in Sri Lanka.

699.76.text: This place is a world garden.

702.10.text:
Young people can be just young people
and be creative and they can make art.

707.82.text:
Outside the garden
people were killing each other.

714.26.text: This was the safe space for children.

716.52.text: Where they could go to create and escape.

721.43.text:
Talking about other aspects
of how art can be powerful.

726.23.text:
This is a guy called “Smokey”.
He is from Burkina Faso.

729.81.text: Smokey is a hip hop artist.

732.52.text:
He recorded an album
and questioned the government.

737.66.text: The album was quite political and strong

745.60.text:
and galvanized young people
to go out on the street.

748.82.text:
So that they could be political
and revolt against the government.

753.30.text:
Because of the power of his album,
the government bombed his studio

757.56.text: and he had to exile the country.

759.65.text:
Again when we think about arts
as a thing people do for entertainment,

766.95.text:
The government felt threatened by it,
so for me it is very powerful.

772.41.text:
Again talking about Rami Assam,
the guy I talked about before.

776.37.text:
He was performing in Tahrir square
when the government was overthrown.

780.36.text:
The greatest thing he did,
he grabbed people from situations,

786.65.text:
some even lived in Tahrir square
for many months

790.19.text:
and his music galvanized the people
and kept them there for this time.

798.00.text:
This is a picture from one of
my favorite countries in the World,

804.65.text: Medellin is a city popular for violence.

812.11.text: It is a city were Pablo Escobar is from,

814.78.text:
a producer
and main distributor of the drug cocaine.

821.23.text:
Young people had
very restricted options in their life.

827.60.text:
Young people from poor neighborhoods
would be in cartels.

832.34.text:
The live expectancy
of young people was 21 years old.

837.13.text:
Between the years of 1987 and 2000,
40.000 young boys were murdered there.

845.29.text:
So the young people decided
to create an alternative

848.67.text:
to their one option
of going into a drug cartel.

854.11.text: They started a hip hop movement.

856.55.text:
They were inspired by hip-hop
in New York in the 1980s.

862.01.text:
And they started break-dancing
and people started to rap across city.

869.98.text:
The consequences were huge
in terms of positive impacts.

873.93.text:
Today there are over 2500 hip-hop acts
in the city.

877.59.text:
That is a thing that changed my mind
about how important art can be.

884.40.text:
This is a hip-hop MC called Lupa.
He said:

887.47.text:
“If it wasn't for hip hop,
I would be dead.

890.15.text:
It gave me an option in life
and for that I’m really thankful.”

894.11.text:
Without being able to do hip-hop,
they would literally have died.

899.93.text:
Hip-hop has become
so important there,

902.89.text:
that there are hip-hop schools
in every commune or neighborhood,

907.83.text: where people learn the forms of hip-hop.

913.61.text: Art has all of these different purposes.

916.16.text:
One of the things I have seen
in war and a lot of conflict zones

922.53.text:
is that the role of women
is often really materialized.

930.35.text:
But art is playing a role
in terms of empowerment of women, too.

936.24.text:
She is an artist,
this woman is from Zimbabwe.

943.79.text:
In her township they suffer
from domestic violence or rape.

951.47.text: These are topics they don't talk about.

956.06.text:
She is 22 years old and the female first
hip-hop artist from the city.

962.04.text:
Through her music she speaks out
against injustices against women.

967.32.text:
That is really powerful,
she is an amazing performer.

970.21.text: For me it does two things.

973.95.text:
Women can have a different option
from fulfilling the traditional roles.

979.00.text:
Secondly it brings to the surface
the issues that women face in a township.

987.16.text:
The next example for the power of art
is my favorite project.

993.80.text:
This is in Uganda in a place
that suffers from many conflicts.

999.85.text:
It is one of the kind
of most challenging places I have seen.

1004.82.text:
This is an organization they call
themselves “HipHop Agribusiness”.

1010.25.text:
This is 15 hip hop artists
and they have a farm and produce food.

1016.96.text:
They sell this and the profit they make
enables them to go to prison

1023.90.text: and do hip-hop workshops with prisoners.

1027.30.text:
The prisoners they work with
generally don’t reoffend.

1031.49.text:
This is the power of hip-hop
to transform opportunities

1035.19.text: for those who are in prison.

1039.11.text:
That is an example
for a true social enterprise.

1044.65.text:
The last example
is one of the most powerful things

1052.48.text: that I have seen in my lifetime,

1054.36.text:
it is the way digital technology
has grown and changed.

1058.11.text:
The power that it has
roots in communities all over the world.

1062.42.text:
This is a photograph of an organization
called “Media Ninja”, based in Brazil.

1068.16.text:
They started by accident
during the up rises in Brazil.

1074.62.text:
One started documenting what happened
on his mobile phone and got arrested.

1083.10.text:
that documents everything
that is happening on the ground.

1085.80.text: They have a huge audience across Brazil.

1088.69.text:
What is powerful
about the creative way of technology,

1093.10.text:
they tell an alternative narrative
to the mainstream media.

1098.35.text: For me this is so powerful.

1100.59.text:
They are able
to tell the stories of the reality

1103.89.text: of what is happening on the streets.

1106.07.text:
Which is often not mentioned
in mainstream media.

1111.75.text:
I encountered in the work
that we do in places of war.

1116.80.text: I could talk about many more.

1119.32.text:
To me art has a capacity
to give people hope.

1123.56.text:
It fills lots of different roles,
it can be a lot of different things

1129.49.text:
but everywhere we go,
we see it happening and being made.

1133.30.text:
When people have hope
they can start to make a change.

1139.59.text:
This is a photograph of me
that might define

1142.17.text: what we think about war zones.

1145.78.text:
But I think right now we are seeing
fundamental changes happening.

1153.55.text: For me this picture is changing.

1156.71.text:
This is in the desert,
where the rules are clearer.

1164.59.text:
Now we have soldiers in our airports,
in our parks and cities across the world.

1172.99.text: For me the biggest change of our time

1175.75.text:
is the changing of the nature
of what a war zone looks like.

1179.49.text: War impacts on every single one of us.

1183.48.text:
I feel like sometimes soldiers
even don't have weapons.

1188.48.text:
Things changed fundamentally in 11/11
when people flew planes into buildings.

1198.75.text:
when we have people
making explosions across cities.

1204.13.text:
The consequences of war
can be felt every single day.

1207.49.text:
With people fleeing from conflicts,
arriving in different countries.

1211.02.text:
Trying to having a better life,
then they are faced with a new conflict.

1219.29.text:
For me art is a way to counter
the violence in the world.

1224.36.text:
It is a way to show solidarity
for the one thing we all have in common,

1234.39.text:
Art is a way for us
to show solidarity for humanity.

1241.11.text:
I hope if you didn't believe
art is important,

1245.58.text:
I showed you in a way
how important it is.

1250.47.text: I still don’t think that that’s enough.

1252.94.text:
If every person in this room
supported an artist in the war zone,

1257.70.text: if every person in this room

1259.46.text:
helps to share the stories
of the most isolated people

1263.21.text:
to counter the narratives
of the mainstream media,

1266.70.text:
if every person in this room
supported the refugee communities,

1270.21.text: than this would be a start.

1272.06.text:
We are living in times of change,
we need to face our children

1276.29.text:
to say that we did some things
to help those who struggle.

1280.67.text:
Because of the impacts
and consequences of conflicts.

1284.86.text:
I want to end with a quote
from a friend from South Africa.

1293.02.text: This summarizes for me the power of art.

1296.95.text: He says: Can poetry change the world?

1300.63.text: I said, can poetry change the world?

1303.57.text:
Poetry can change people,
and people can change the world.

1322.45.text: Let’s see, hands going up for questions.

1328.15.text: We can take one or two maybe.

1336.39.text: I have a couple if you like? - Sure.

1342.20.text:
There are so many moving stories
and personal impressions.

1347.21.text:
How do you manage to take all this home
and keep the dynamic in going?

1352.92.text:
I guess it is the people
we are working with across the world.

1356.67.text:
We are working with young people
with this drive and passion.

1362.31.text:
These are the most brave people
working in the most challenging context.

1368.42.text: I am always inspired by what I see.

1372.35.text:
The work we do
is how we can support these people

1375.41.text:
and tell their stories
on a global platform.

1377.92.text:
The fire of the people I work with
give me the fire to take that forward.

1382.49.text:
Sometimes what we see in the field
can be really hard.

1389.09.text:
For me it is that resilience in people
who are creating this kind of art

1393.44.text:
that gives me the drive
to give that a bigger platform I guess.

1405.02.text: We are expanding what we are doing.

1406.85.text: We want to work across more countries.

1409.23.text:
A lot of stuff we are doing
around entrepreneurism and education

1413.92.text: and more contexts across the world.

1416.83.text:
As long as there is a need
to support artists around the world

1422.29.text: we will continue to do this work.

1425.76.text:
It is great.
Thank you so so much.

1427.66.text: You can hang out at the Makerspace.

1431.41.text:
And for those
who are too shy for questions now.

1435.87.text:
Find us there
to take the opportunity tomorrow maybe.

1441.95.text: And find more about your work.

1444.17.text:
Thanks so much for being here,
have another round of applause please.
